qas.question: To whom did the Security Council officially refer the situation in Darfur?

answers.text: Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court

qas.question: What was taken into account, without mentioning specific crimes?
China and what other permanent member of the Security Council abstained from the vote on the referral resolution?
In which number report to the Council did the Prosecutor concede that crimes had been committed but evidence for prosecution was insufficient?

plausible_answers.text: Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court

qas.question: To whom did the Security Council officially refer the situation in China?
What was taken into account without mentioning specific councils?
China and what other permanent member of the Security Council abstained from the vote on crimes?
In which number report to the Council did the Prosecutor concede that crimes had been committed but evidence for prosecution was sufficient?
When did the Security Council formally refer the situation in Darfur to China?

context: In <b8_0>March 2005<b8_0/>, the Security Council formally referred the situation in Darfur to the <a0_0><b4_0>Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court<b4_0/><a0_0/>, taking into account <a1_0><b5_0>the Commission report<b5_0/><a1_0/> but without mentioning any specific crimes. Two permanent members of the Security Council, <a2_0><b6_0>the United States<b6_0/><a2_0/> and China, abstained from the vote on the referral resolution. As of <a3_0><b7_0>his fourth report<b7_0/><a3_0/> to the Security Council, the Prosecutor has found "reasonable grounds to believe that the individuals identified [in the UN Security Council Resolution 1593] have committed crimes against humanity and war crimes," but did not find sufficient evidence to prosecute for genocide.
